It's been nearly 3 year since my purchase.
Amazon and Smilegate did a horrible job and continues to bring this title to the west; they continue to either use basic non-MMO marketing logic or ignorance to the west depending on which company you look at.

The game was fun, when 1 million people were around. 
It is not fun when the 9 others I started with have quit.
This game is designed to be played with 7 other people - 20 hours+ a week. In unison. 
You must also be willing to spend either an extra 40 hours a week to grind materials or drop 25-100 dollars a week on this game to meet upgrade requirements.

As of this review, if you intend to play and are a 100% completionist - stop. You will be missing multiple wallpapers, 1-time-event things etc ... unless they drop some FRESH servers with the old Tier 1-2-3 system, you'll never get those achievements.

If you are SOLO, you will not enjoy this game.

You've been warned.

Review:
completion: I kept hearing about the amazing endgame and how much content there was, but the farther along I got the more I realized that entire "game" is just a thinly veiled marketing vector that throws a shit ton of stamina or time-gated systems at you to annoy you into spending money to get past them or make some grinds more rewarding. There's a huge difference between a game designed to be fun, and a game designed to be engaging, and I feel like a lot of people struggle to understand that. Lost Ark's business strategy is literally create a problem to sell a solution. I'm convinced everyone who still plays it just has Stockholm syndrome, because that's what it felt like to me in hindsight. Once I finally got off for longer than a week, the only feelings I could ascribe to the whole experience was a sensation akin to finding out someone I'd been hanging out with was only around to get me to buy things for them.

Write a positive Steam user review for the game "Cyberpunk 2077".

Guidelines:

Review:
completion:
Very few times in life have I felt truly involved and invested in a story. Actually caring what happens.  Cyberpunk 2077 and the expansion (Phantom Liberty) have somehow pulled it off.  The story is masterfully written.  The visuals are amazing,  the characters are interesting and the world building is exceptional. I felt I had to explore every single pixel. There are hidden things everywhere.  Currently I have 900 hours played and I am still finding things I've never seen.
Id recommend this to any gamer (and even non gamers) 100%.
That said the game does have some bugs and limitations,  Though nothing major that cant be addressed with mods or just ignored.
Photo mode is amazing, but I would like to see more freedom in it. Like a free pose mode and the ability to use it anywhere at anytime no matter the action.  

Finally the modding scene is EXPANSIVE. There is an almost endless amount of customization available.  
CDPR pulled this game from a pile of crap (at release) into an expertly cut gem. 5/5

Grand Theft Auto: San Andreas ‚Äì The Definitive Edition tries to bring a beloved classic into the modern era, but the results are somewhat uneven. The core of San Andreas‚Äîits sprawling world, rich story, and addictive gameplay‚Äîremains just as engaging and nostalgic as ever. Exploring Los Santos, San Fierro, and Las Venturas with Carl ‚ÄúCJ‚Äù Johnson‚Äôs journey through gang wars, corruption, and personal redemption is timeless. The Definitive Edition improves on textures, lighting, and character models, aiming to deliver a fresher visual experience. However, these upgrades often fall short of expectations, with inconsistent graphics, awkward animations, and technical hiccups that occasionally disrupt immersion. Controls and user interface improvements inspired by newer Rockstar titles are welcome, making gameplay smoother than the original. While longtime fans might appreciate the nostalgia and newcomers get a chance to experience a GTA classic, the Definitive Edition struggles to fully honor the original‚Äôs legacy due to its rough execution. Still, beneath the flaws lies a sprawling and memorable adventure that remains one of the most influential open-world games ever made.

Rating: 7/10

completion:
Hot characters, flashy raids, and interesting lore. Some of the negative feedback that I saw in the reviews mentioned gatekeeping of raids and a pay-to-win (P2W) system, so let me share my perspective on them.

Gatekeeping of raids: If you join an active guild and put in the effort to find the right people to play with, they will raid with any class you have. If you prefer not to be friends with other gamers, you can create your own raid lobby and label it accordingly, such as 'learning party' if you are just starting out or 'hw party' if you are well-experienced. You might be surprised by how many people are waiting to join you.

P2W: Frequent events, shops, and daily prizes provide a good amount for you to level up. While it might take a while, the progression is meant to be more like a 'stroll in the park.' Appreciate the quests and the storyline, farm some mokokos, and work on collecting items and enjoy the game fully.

Other than some toxic players ruining the raid, I've met really good friends through this game who are miles away from me. The new update with the Breaker is coming out soon and it will have lots of modifications to players needs and I am here for it.

Review:
completion:
[h1]Overall[/h1]
This game is long-term game. 
You definitely would have to invest a some amount of time and consistency to play for fun.
(not like 100 hours or 300 hours)

It does require pretty expensive rig. 
Unlike League of Legends, and WOW, this game has a lot of in-game features and particles to render.
You may be required a computer with high specifications for playable quality.

[h1]Currency[/h1]
After spending around a couple hundreds of dollars (mostly Ark-pass, monthly buffs, and skins), I can tell this game is clearly playable as F2P. 
It's your choice to spend an amount of money to become stronger quick. 
However, in the end, everyone will be in a similar level (unless you decided to dump a car in it).

[h1]Newcomers[/h1]
For newcomers, I would recommend start playing whenever there is a major event (such as Super Mokoko Express, etc.).
and try enjoying the stories (some of them are actually impressive).
I personally better recommend to play with friend who's been playing for quite awhile.

*PLEASE*
If you have any question while playing game, google it, ask in-game chat, or post question in the official LostArk Discord server.
(https://discord.gg/lostark)

completion: They fixed most of the issues the game had at launch. There's a solo mode now (although it's much more demanding on your computer) and most of the heists are at least somewhat fun. Battlefield 2042 is a good game. But it is one of if not the worst Battlefields of them all.
A good portion of the maps are wide open, making camping with snipers the only playstyle that is actually viable. 
That being said, the idea of weather effects really creates some unique experiences.
Weapons are average at best. Most of the guns you'll encounter are meta weapons since they really have a big advantage over some of the weaker guns. Take the PP as an example.
Play this game if you like large scale battles. But consider spending a bit more and just buy Battlefield 6 if you want a more 'classic' Battlefield experience

Build wise, the experimentation is pretty much endless as well. Whether you want to be a hulking knight with a slab of iron, a cosmic pew-pew sorcerer raining stars from the sky, a nimble samurai or a Bonk Boi with a massive hammer, the game has something for you.

Review:
completion:
So we start with the PC port coming from the PS2, then we have a mobile port done by devs who have no idea what they're doing, then we have a PC port based on THAT mobile version by the same devs (no longer credited btw).

This trilogy is a disgrace to humanity; most of the positive reviews didn't even play past Los Santos.

The definitive edition is an overexpensive coat of paint over an old engine (it's actually true, it's still using the old Renderware engine, but the visuals are handled by Unreal Engine).

Physics are broken, no super sprint, swimming is slow. (Funny enough, fixed on the mobile DE version but no luck for PC gamers!)

Unless you're REALLY interested in achievements, just get yourself the original, downgrade the game if needed, and add the community fixes (SilentPatch, Widescreen, Framerate Vigilante, etc.) and your experience will be MILES better.

completion:
This is the first time playing this style of game, and I've seen both the good and bad reviews. I figured I'd give it a shot, but after 10.9 hours of attempt - with two different characters - I'm throwing in the towel.

While it appears there is a plethora of content, the various areas of the game clearly are locked behind high-level bosses who one-/two-shot players. Even within the early area of the game, there are mini-boss characters who absolutely wreck, without the player having a chance apart from staying out of their view. Going into a swampy area and heading toward a small island resulted in a massive dragon that dropped out of the sky and one-shot'd me without so much as a "Good evening, crunchy!"

Apart from the actual play, the menus are not intuitive but instead seem to be an after-thought. Figuring out how things work, where to go to set up primary- and secondary-arrows for bows required looking information up online instead of any tutorial. The learning curve is exceptionally steep while the enjoyment factor is low.

Unfortunately I'll be asking Steam for a refund. One day of playing this was far more than enough for me.

Review:
completion:
I really liked this game. I would say the story can get a bit confusing at parts. I also felt underwhelmed by the main plotline. It wasn't as interesting as I'd hoped. The witcher series had a much more enjoyable and interesting story line. I felt that the games atmosphere, gameplay and graphics is where it really shines. The gameplay is very in depth. You can take fighting to many different areas of expertise. You can be crafty and become a net runner, disabling attackers with net attacks. You can take the exact opposite and be more of a brawler and use melee weapons. The enemy combatants also take many different modes of attack towards you as well. So overall I would recommend the game as it shines in many areas and the part where it didn't shine in the story it made up for in it's other positives.

for short
Positives
+Atmosphere
+Gameplay
+Graphics

If you like:
-Bladerunner

-Akira
-Altered Carbon
-Robocop
-Total Recall
-The Matrix
-Deus Ex
-Psycho Pass
Then you'll love this.

The only thing missing is CyberGwent and gambling.
Extremely excited for what comes next.

Oh, Battlefield 2042‚Ä¶ what a disaster you started out as.

I originally bought the game on PlayStation back in 2021. While I managed to put in around 70 hours and had some fun, it was impossible to ignore how disappointing it felt. For a franchise that‚Äôs so close to my heart, it was clear that the game lacked many of the qualities that made earlier entries shine.

Recently, I decided to reinstall it thanks to a discount and some unlocks for BF6. To my surprise, much has been improved, and I ended up sinking another 60 hours into it.

The game still feels a little soulless and generic at times, but there‚Äôs definitely fun to be had. One of my favorite aspects is the sense of scale that comes with 128 player Conquest. The addition of weekly missions pushes me to experiment with different weapons and tactics, which keeps things fresh. Text and voice chat have finally been added, and some genuinely great maps too. Plus, the cringey voice lines? Gone.

Final Verdict:

Launch: 6/10

Now: 7.5/10

I‚Äôm cautiously optimistic about Battlefield 6, but I can only hope EA doesn‚Äôt crush those dreams‚Äîas they‚Äôve done before

+Weather system adds a random chaotic element that I enjoyed (Tornadoes in particular were thrilling)

+Great vehicle variety with interesting twists on every form of transport

Cons
-Horrendously clunky and awkward movement/gun-play
-Character designs scream "Modern Audience", completely ruining the Battlefield aesthetic
-Audio is the worst in the series and voiced lines were all cringe inducing

Review:
completion:
Hands down one of the best games I've played.
I'd initally picked up this game at launch, but dropped it due to the performance issues. I'd been hearing that things are way better recently, so I picked it up again. For starters, the graphics are fantastic, night city really does feel like a real city, and it's clear a lot of effort went into making it so. The combat is fun and engaging, although it does slowly become too easy even at the hardest difficulty (if you engage in all the side content). Towards the end of the game I found myself breezing through main story battles and boss encounters with ease which did make them feel slightly anti climactic. 
Now to the main highlight of the game - the story. Fantastic plot lines all round, great voice acting across the board. The game does a great job at making you feel the weight of decisions you make not only in the main story but also in the side quests which is so rare. I found myself actually deliberating before making choices and feeling hurt or at best left with a bittersweet feeling at the end of most quests.
Would wholeheartedly recommend this game.
